importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which systematic torture in Israeli prisons became widely documented, with testimonies from 100 detainees and reports of deaths, prompting international human rights bodies to raise alarms.

keyTakeAways: Palestinian detainees, including Mahmoud Abu Foul, have reported severe torture and loss of vision in Israeli prisons, particularly at Sde Teiman, described as a 'prison that breaks men'.
Abu Foul, a 28-year-old from northern Gaza, lost his sight after being beaten on the head and denied proper medical treatment during detention.
The U.S.-brokered ceasefire deal released nearly 2,000 Palestinian detainees, many of whom show visible signs of abuse or have lost significant body weight.
The Palestinian Centre for Human Rights documented systematic torture across all Israeli prison facilities between October 2023 and 2024, not isolated to Sde Teiman.

Israel has returned at least 100 bodies of detainees who died in custody, with medical evidence suggesting possible executions, and the UN estimates at least 75 detainees have died since October 2023.

Human rights groups like B’Tselem and Physicians for Human Rights – Israel describe the prison system as a network of torture camps involving physical abuse, denial of medical care, and sexual violence.
Despite hundreds of abuse reports, Israeli authorities have charged only in two cases, with no prison service personnel indicted, according to PCATI.
Israel’s National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir has defended harsh treatment of Palestinian prisoners and has been linked to taunting of high-profile detainee Marwan Barghouti.
Marwan Barghouti’s son claims his father was beaten in prison in September, and family members report testimonies of abuse during transfer between prisons.
Approximately 9,000 Palestinian prisoners remain in Israeli jails without trial or legal process, raising concerns about due process and human rights violations.

namedEntities.name: Mahmoud Abu Foul
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 28-year-old Palestinian man from northern Gaza who was arrested in late December 2023 and subjected to torture in Israeli detention, resulting in blindness and denial of medical care.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central subject of the article, providing firsthand testimony of torture, loss of sight, and the psychological trauma of detention.

namedEntities.name: Sde Teiman prison
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli detention facility described by detainees as 'the prison that breaks men', where Mahmoud Abu Foul endured repeated beatings and torture.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is cited as a site of systematic abuse and torture, reinforcing claims of a broader, institutionalized pattern of mistreatment in Israeli prisons.

namedEntities.name: Kamal Adwan Hospital
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A hospital in Beit Lahiya, northern Gaza, where Mahmoud Abu Foul was arrested from.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It marks the point of arrest, indicating the intersection of healthcare and detention, and underscores the vulnerability of medical facilities in conflict zones.

namedEntities.name: Nasser Hospital
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The hospital where Mahmoud Abu Foul was transferred upon release from Israeli detention.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents the medical aftermath of detention, where survivors continue to face unmet health needs and lack of treatment for torture-related injuries.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The U.S. is central to the geopolitical mechanism that enabled the release of detainees, drawing international attention to the human rights crisis in Israeli prisons.

namedEntities.name: Palestinian Centre for Human Rights (PCHR)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization that documented testimonies from 100 former detainees between October 2023 and 2024, finding widespread torture across Israeli prisons.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides authoritative evidence of systematic abuse, strengthening the claim that torture is not isolated but institutionalized in Israeli detention facilities.

namedEntities.name: B’Tselem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli human rights group that described the prison system as a 'network of torture camps' with systematic physical abuse and denial of care.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It adds credibility to the allegations of torture through independent observation and reporting from within Israel's system.

namedEntities.name: Physicians for Human Rights – Israel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization led by Dr. Ruchama Marton, which has campaigned for decades against torture in Israeli prisons.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It reflects long-term advocacy and underscores the persistence of torture despite international attention and warnings.

namedEntities.name: Public Committee Against Torture in Israel (PCATI)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli rights group that documents torture cases and reports that only two incidents have led to indictments, with no prison staff charged.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a political figure directly linked to policy decisions in prisons and has publicly defended or mocked detainee treatment, contributing to the perception of institutional normalization of torture.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A high-profile Palestinian political leader and detainee who has been subject to allegations of physical abuse in prison, including being beaten during a transfer.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His case illustrates targeted abuse and political persecution by Israeli authorities, reinforcing the claim of systemic and ideological torture.

namedEntities.name: Arab Barghouti

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His statements provide corroboration of abuse allegations and highlight familial and emotional stakes in the ongoing human rights crisis.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mahmoud Abu Foul, a 28-year-old Palestinian from northern Gaza, suffered severe torture during detention in Israeli prisons, including a head injury that resulted in complete blindness and denial of medical treatment. His case is part of a broader pattern of systematic abuse documented by organizations like the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights and B’Tselem, which report that torture is widespread across Israeli prison facilities, including at Sde Teiman. Over 2,000 Palestinian detainees were released under a U.S.-brokered ceasefire, many of whom bear visible physical and psychological scars from abuse. The article also highlights that at least 75 Palestinian detainees have died in Israeli prisons since October 2023, with evidence suggesting executions, and that no prison staff have been charged despite hundreds of reports. Key figures like Itamar Ben-Gvir and Marwan Barghouti are directly involved in the political and punitive environment of detention, with reports of targeted violence and abuse. The situation underscores a deep, institutionalized human rights crisis in Israeli prisons, where detainees are denied legal access, medical care, and basic dignity.
title: Palestinian detainee relays how torture in Israeli prison made him blind
